When a small group of organisms (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (e.g., when it crosses a mountain range or a river, or when it migrates to a new island, so that it cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations in order to be a strong competitor, as opposed to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
Over time, the new population begins to adapt to its new environment, and it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations may look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from technology-push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by the underlying logic that is associated with scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. One, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely beyond the influence of cultural or political forces, and two, that technology itself has "effects" on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could say that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the field of medicine to repair damaged bodies.
